title: Rio Tinto on track for iron ore crown
text:
Rio Tinto is on track to be the world's biggest exporter of iron ore in 2019 after improved performance over the past three months, but the miner has been forced to lower its bauxite and alumina production targets.

Rio shipped 86.1 million tonnes of iron ore in the three months to September 30; exactly in line with UBS forecasts.

The shipments were higher than the previous quarter and the same period of 2018, despite Rio losing use of its railway for five days of maintenance in the quarter.

The result was an improvement on a horror June quarter, when mine planning problems forced the company to lower its iron ore export guidance for the second time in 2019.

There was no further change to iron ore guidance on Wednesday, meaning the company expects to ship between 320 million and 330 million tonnes in the year to December 31.

Rio would hit the upper end of that guidance if it repeated the export performance of the past three months, and the company traditionally ships more iron ore in the three months to December 31 than in any other period of the year.
description: Problems in the Pacific region have forced the miner to cut bauxite and alumina targets, but its flagship iron ore division appears to be regaining form.
